summary: This document is an email chain between prosecutors and defense counsel in the US v. Maxwell case, primarily concerning discovery disputes over highly confidential (HC) photographic and video evidence seized from Jeffrey Epstein's properties. The correspondence reveals confusion and discrepancies in the number of HC images provided to the defense, with the government initially stating ~5,500 images but an FBI 302 report indicating over 34,000. It details logistical arrangements for the defense to review evidence in Colorado and New York, and touches on issues with document formats and accessibility.

persons.name: Laura Menninger
persons.context: Partner at Haddon, Morgan & Foreman, P.C. representing Ghislaine Maxwell. She is corresponding with prosecutors about significant discrepancies in the count of highly confidential (HC) images and videos provided in discovery, and arranging for evidence review.

persons.name: Jeff Pagliuca
persons.role: Contractor (US Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York)
persons.context: Listed as a contractor for the US Attorney's Office (USANYS) copied on the email chain regarding discovery issues in US v. Maxwell.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the case 'US v. Maxwell'. Her counsel is arranging for her to review discovery materials, including highly confidential images, at the Metropolitan Detention Center (MDC).

persons.name: Chris Everdell
persons.context: Mentioned as having reviewed HC images with Ghislaine Maxwell at the MDC in the fall of 2020, as noted by the prosecutor.

persons.name: Bobbi Sternheim
persons.context: Copied on several emails within the chain regarding discovery deficiencies and conferral.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The source of the seized evidence. HC images and videos were recovered from his electronic devices and CDs seized from his New York and Virgin Islands residences during his arrest and searches.

connections.description: Menninger is the defense attorney representing Maxwell, as evidenced by her advocating for Maxwell's right to review discovery materials and corresponding on her behalf.
The evidence being discussed (images/videos from Epstein's devices) is central to the case against Maxwell, implying their alleged prior association.
They are on opposing sides of the case (defense and prosecution) communicating to resolve discovery issues.
Everdell reviewed discovery materials with Maxwell at the MDC in 2020.

events.title: HC Image Review at MDC
events.description: FBI agents brought a drive containing HC images from CDs for Chris Everdell to review with Ghislaine Maxwell at the Metropolitan Detention Center (MDC).

events.title: Second HC Image Review at MDC
events.description: FBI agents brought a drive containing HC images from CDs for a second review session with Ghislaine Maxwell at the MDC.

events.title: Evidence Review at 500 Pearl Street
events.description: Defense counsel Laura Menninger reviewed evidence, including two hard drives said to contain HC images, at 500 Pearl Street in New York.

events.title: Production of De-designated Confidential Materials
events.description: Approximately 7,721 images previously designated as HC were de-designated and produced as confidential materials to the defense.

events.title: Discovery Dispute Correspondence
events.description: Email chain reveals ongoing confusion and a request for preservation of evidence drives, highlighting a major discrepancy in the number of HC images provided to the defense.

locations: 500 Pearl Street, New York, NY (Location where evidence was reviewed)
Metropolitan Detention Center (MDC) (Where Ghislaine Maxwell was held and reviewed evidence)
Denver, CO (Location of FBI field office where evidence was to be sent for review)
New York residence of Jeffrey Epstein (Source of seized CDs)
Virgin Islands residence of Jeffrey Epstein (Source of seized electronic devices)
St. Andrews Plaza, New York, NY 10007 (Address of the Assistant U.S. Attorney)
keyFacts: A significant discrepancy existed in the number of Highly Confidential (HC) images/videos: the defense was initially told ~5,500 were available for review, but an FBI 302 report indicated 33,747 HC images and 895 HC videos (over 34,000 files) were recovered from Epstein's devices.

The HC evidence came from two primary sources: 1) CDs seized from Epstein's New York residence, and 2) electronic devices seized from Epstein during his arrest and searches of his NY and Virgin Islands residences.
The defense faced major technical hurdles in reviewing discovery, including corrupt files, missing metadata, unreadable file formats, and difficulties accessing materials for their client at the MDC.
The prosecution was undertaking a de-designation process to reclassify HC images that did not depict genitals, breasts, or buttocks down to a Confidential level for production to the defense.

The email chain shows pre-trial tensions over discovery compliance, with the defense expressing concern about receiving the bulk of photographic evidence just two months before the then-scheduled November 2021 trial.
